diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by symptoms like anemia, hand edema, and can also cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. Hand edema and anemia are common symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: A contagious illness often spread through saliva. It can cause fatigue, fever, swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), and spleen enlargement.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: An acute febrile illness of young children characterized by inflammation of blood vessels throughout the body. It leads to symptoms like hand edema, tongue erythema, and cervical lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: An infection that can develop in people who have strep throat. It's characterized by a bright red rash on the body, fever, and tongue erythema.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer of the blood and bone marrow with excessive production of abnormal white blood cells. It can cause symptoms like anemia, hand edema, and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. Systemic symptoms can include anemia and swelling in lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Glomerulonephritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the tiny filters in your kidneys (glomeruli). It can lead to symptoms like urine abnormalities (pyuria), high blood pressure, and facial edema.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A disease caused by the human immunodeficiency virus. It can lead to reduced immunity and increased susceptibility to infections, presenting with symptoms like lymphadenopathy, anemia, and hand edema.

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels that can cause bleeding in the skin, joints, intestines, and kidneys. Symptoms can include hand edema and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, presenting with a wide range of symptoms including fever, rash (often erythematous-violaceous), and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Adult-Onset Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by fever, rash (often erythematous), and arthritis. It can also lead to complications like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that begins in lymphocytes (T-cells or B-cells), which are part of the immune system. Symptoms can include fever, delirium due to systemic illness or metabolic disturbances, thrombocytopenia, and pericardial effusion as a result of cancer invasion or obstruction.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves (endocardium) that can produce symptoms such as fever, heart murmurs, petechial rash (which can be mistaken for an erythematous-violaceous rash), thrombocytopenia, and delirium.

diagnoses.name: Viral Hemorrhagic Fevers (e.g., Dengue, Ebola)
diagnoses.description: A group of illnesses caused by several distinct families of viruses. Characterized by fever, thrombocytopenia, and in severe cases, hemorrhagic symptoms. Some may experience a rash or issues like pericardial effusion.

diagnoses.name: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC)
diagnoses.description: A serious disorder in which the proteins responsible for blood clotting become overactive. Symptoms can include bleeding, fever, thrombocytopenia, and potentially organ failure symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by thrombosis and/or pregnancy complications, in association with the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies. It can lead to symptoms like thrombocytopenia, fever, and cognitive dysfunction (delirium).

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder that exhibits features commonly seen in lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis, including fever, muscle weakness, rash, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia. It can present with symptoms like fever and an erythematous-violaceous rash as part of autoimmune activity.

diagnoses.name: Septicemia
diagnoses.description: A severe infection that spreads through the bloodstream, leading to symptoms like fever, confusion or delirium, and thrombocytopenia as a consequence of disseminated coagulation or direct bacterial invasion.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can affect multiple systems including the central nervous system (leading to psychosis and delirium), joints (arthropathy and synovitis), and pericardium (acute pericarditis).

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily known for causing inflammatory arthritis, in severe cases or specific variants, it can lead to systemic involvement including pericarditis and rarely CNS involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Aside from its hallmark exocrinopathies, can have systemic manifestations including arthritis and nervous system involvement. Pericarditis is less common but possible.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Certain viral infections can lead to acute pericarditis, synovitis, and CNS involvement including delirium and less commonly, psychosis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Caused by Borrelia burgdorferi, it can lead to neurological manifestations (Lyme neuroborreliosis), arthritis, and in rare instances, cardiac involvement.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: A multisystem granulomatous disease which can affect the joints (arthropathy), lungs, skin, and rarely the heart (pericarditis) and central nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by features of several connective tissue diseases including SLE, systemic sclerosis, and polymyositis. It can present with arthritis, pericarditis, and neurological manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A vasculitis that can cause arthritis, CNS involvement including psychosis, and vascular complications that might indirectly affect the heart.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily known for its vascular complications, it can indirectly cause a variety of systemic manifestations including those affecting the joints, CNS, and heart.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily a heart valve infection, it can cause a variety of systemic manifestations including embolic phenomena leading to CNS involvement including delirium and indirectly causing joint pain or arthropathy through immune complex deposition.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infection
diagnoses.description: Many viral infections can cause a combination of pericardial and pleural effusions along with fever and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Bacterial Infection
diagnoses.description: Bacterial infections, particularly those caused by pneumococcus or staphylococcus, can lead to these symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as lupus (systemic lupus erythematosus) and rheumatoid arthritis can present with these symptoms due to their inflammatory nature.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.description: Tuberculosis can cause pericarditis and effusions in both the pericardial and pleural spaces.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: Uremia, or the build-up of waste products in the blood due to kidney failure, can cause pericarditis and effusions.

diagnoses.name: Cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancers, particularly those metastasizing to the pericardium or pleura, can cause effusions and inflammation leading to fever and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Radiation Therapy
diagnoses.description: Radiation therapy to the chest for cancer treatment can induce pericarditis and effusions.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced
diagnoses.description: Certain medications can cause pericarditis and effusions, including those for treating cancer, hypertension, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Trauma
diagnoses.description: Physical trauma to the chest can lead to pericardial and pleural effusions and inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Mycoplasma Infection
diagnoses.description: Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection can sometimes lead to pericarditis and pleural effusions, accompanied by fever.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Conditions where the immune system mistakenly attacks the body, potentially explaining the range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease/Cirrhosis
diagnoses.description: Chronic liver conditions may lead to abnormal liver enzymes and can be linked with systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that often presents with dryness of the mouth, which can lead to oral leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Can present with a wide variety of symptoms including pneumonia, oral leukoplakia (HIV-associated leukoplakia), and abnormal liver enzymes.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to a compromised immune system, possibly resulting in recurrent infections like pneumonia and otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Often associated with various systemic symptoms and can impact other organs' functionalities indirectly.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that can occur after an allogeneic tissue transplant and could explain a wide spectrum of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: A condition that affects the liver, leading to abnormal liver enzymes and can be associated with other autoimmune symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Non-Alcoholic Fatty Liver Disease (NAFLD)
diagnoses.description: Can lead to abnormal liver enzymes and is associated with other metabolic syndrome components.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Certain types of lymphoma could explain the pulmonary symptoms, abnormal liver enzymes, and leukoplakia due to immune suppression.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased appetite and difficulty focusing vision can be symptoms of high blood glucose levels. Hypertension is a common comorbidity.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Abnormal electrolytes, hypertension, and difficulty focusing vision could be related to kidney function decline.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reasoning: Increased appetite and difficulty focusing vision can be symptoms; abnormal electrolytes can occur secondary to metabolic changes.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: Symptoms may include hypertension, increased appetite, and abnormal electrolyte balances.

diagnoses.name: Primary Hyperaldosteronism
diagnoses.reasoning: This could explain hypertension and abnormal electrolytes; the other symptoms may be less directly related.

diagnoses.name: Conn's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: A type of primary hyperaldosteronism that can cause hypertension and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Acute Sinusitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Post-nasal drip is a primary symptom; other symptoms might be less directly related but could be secondary effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.reasoning: Persistent post-nasal drip is a symptom; can lead to secondary hypertension in rare cases due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.reasoning: May cause increased appetite and abnormal electrolytes; hypertension can occur in compensatory mechanisms.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare tumor of the adrenal gland can cause hypertension, difficulty focusing vision, and abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses: Secondary Osteoporosis due to an Underlying Disorder
Otitis Media with Effusion due to Allergic Reactions

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: PCOS can cause menstrual irregularities such as menorrhagia and dysmenorrhea. Though not directly causing increased immunoglobulins, systemic inflammation associated with PCOS might affect immune parameters.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Hypothyroidism can cause menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and could potentially contribute to obstructive sleep apnea due to myxedematous changes in the oropharyngeal tissues. Autoimmune thyroid diseases like Hashimoto's thyroiditis can lead to increased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: While not directly causing the listed menstrual problems, chronic fatigue syndrome is associated with immune system deregulation, which might be reflected in increased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Primarily associated with obstructive sleep apnea, conditions affecting sleep can indirectly impact menstrual cycles by disrupting the circadian rhythm and possibly hormonal regulation.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.reason: These can cause an increase in immunoglobulin levels due to excessive production of lymphocytes. While not directly related to the gynecological symptoms, systemic illnesses could indirectly affect menstrual regularity and volume.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.reason: Several autoimmune disorders, such as systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), can cause increased immunoglobulins and may have manifestations such as menorrhagia or dysmenorrhea due to their systemic nature.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Infections
diagnoses.reason: Certain long-standing infections can lead to elevated immunoglobulin levels as part of the immune response. Indirect effects or treatment side effects might contribute to menstrual irregularities.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.reason: Often a consequence of menorrhagia, it can lead to laryngitis due to tissue hypoxia and potential mucosal changes. Obstructive sleep apnea could exacerbate the fatigue associated with anemia.

diagnoses.name: Obesity
diagnoses.reason: Can cause or worsen obstructive sleep apnea and is a risk factor for PCOS, which in turn is associated with dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. Obesity might also be an inflammatory state which could affect immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Although primarily a condition characterized by widespread pain and fatigue, fibromyalgia can coexist with sleep disturbances like obstructive sleep apnea and might have an association with immune system abnormalities.

diagnoses: Hashimoto's Thyroiditis leading to transient hyperthyroidism
Hyperthyroidism due to functioning adenoma or goiter

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Poor healing and atherosclerosis are common complications. In severely uncontrolled cases, other symptoms may worsen due to compromised blood flow and immune response.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: This autoimmune disease can cause dysphagia due to dry mouth, and systemic features may include lymphadenitis. Secondary complications might include skin manifestations like folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV)
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause lymphadenitis as an early symptom and lead to poor healing. Folliculitis is more common in HIV-positive patients due to immune suppression.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune disease that can cause widespread inflammation, including lymphadenitis and skin conditions like folliculitis. Atherosclerosis can be an associated risk due to chronic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Primary symptom is often lymphadenitis. Other systemic symptoms like poor healing and a degree of dysphagia (if lesions affect the GI tract or thoracic area) can occur.

diagnoses.name: Squamous Cell Carcinoma of the Esophagus
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly causes dysphagia and may be associated with paraneoplastic syndromes that could explain lymphadenitis and poor healing.

diagnoses.name: Tuberculosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause lymphadenitis (especially in the neck, known as scrofula). Immune response to the infection might be compromised, leading to poor healing and increased susceptibility to other infections causing folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Causes vascular inflammation leading to symptoms like poor healing and possibly atherosclerosis. Folliculitis and other skin manifestations are common. Lymphadenopathy and dysphagia could be related to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare condition that affects blood vessels and could lead to symptoms like poor healing due to impaired circulation, atherosclerosis, and others due to systemic inflammation including possibly dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.reasoning: Secondary stage can present with lymphadenopathy and skin conditions like folliculitis. Tertiary syphilis can cause atherosclerosis. Gummatous syphilis can result in poor healing ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Reactions
diagnoses.description: Could manifest as Kounis syndrome (a type of acute coronary syndrome triggered by allergic reactions), with skin manifestations such as folliculitis, and potentially affect immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Certain autoimmune conditions can lead to decreased immunoglobulins, skin issues like folliculitis, and neurological symptoms that might manifest as blepharospasm.

diagnoses.name: Parasitic Infections
diagnoses.description: Conditions like scabies or lice could cause migratory pruritus and folliculitis due to the skin reaction to the parasites. If extensive, the skin's condition could potentially affect overall immune response.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Hepatitis
diagnoses.description: Can lead to decreased immunoglobulin levels, and some patients might experience skin conditions as part of their symptomatology. Liver stress can exacerbate reactions such as Kounis syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Hodgkin's Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the immune system can lead to decreased immunoglobulins and may present with itchy skin (pruritus) but is less likely to directly cause the other symptoms unless related to overall body inflammation or reactions to treatment.

diagnoses.name: Dermatologic Conditions
diagnoses.description: Chronic skin conditions such as eczema or psoriasis might lead to folliculitis and migratory pruritus. Secondary effects could include eye involvement (blepharospasm) from irritation.

diagnoses.name: Immunodeficiency Disorders
diagnoses.description: Primary or acquired disorders that affect the immune system can lead to decreased immunoglobulins and make the individual more susceptible to skin infections or conditions like folliculitis.

diagnoses.name: Chemical Exposures
diagnoses.description: Exposure to certain chemicals or toxins could precipitate allergic reactions leading to Kounis syndrome, impact the immune system to decrease immunoglobulin levels, and cause skin reactions.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A common inflammatory skin disease marked by itchy and inflamed patches on the skin, which could also lead to complications such as folliculitis due to scratching and secondary skin infections.

diagnoses.name: Nutritional Deficiencies
diagnoses.description: Certain deficiencies in the diet can lead to decreased immunoglobulin levels, skin problems like folliculitis, and generally lower the body's immune response to allergens and irritants.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin D Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin D deficiency can cause bone pain and muscle weakness. Symptoms may be mild at first but can become more severe, leading to conditions like osteoporosis. It could indirectly contribute to attention deficit through its effects on overall health, but it's less directly linked to blepharospasm and malabsorption, although malabsorption issues can lead to or worsen vitamin D deficiency.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: Multiple Sclerosis (MS) is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It can lead to fatigue, muscle control issues, and spasticity, which might be related to symptoms like blepharospasm. Attention deficits can also be a cognitive symptom of MS.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing malabsorption. It can lead to various symptoms including bone pain due to nutrient deficiencies like calcium and vitamin D. Attention deficits and neurological issues can also be a part of its wide-ranging effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Chronic sinusitis can cause a persistent state of sinus inflammation, leading to symptoms like sinus pain but it's less directly related to the other symptoms listed. It could contribute to a general feeling of malaise that aggravates other conditions.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, primarily the lungs and lymph glands. It can cause a wide array of symptoms, including bone pain and sinusitis. Malabsorption and attention deficit issues could potentially arise from the overall impact of sarcoidosis on the body's well-being.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia is a disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. While it prominently causes bone and muscle pain, it can lead to concentration difficulties (sometimes referred to as 'fibro fog'). However, blepharospasm and malabsorption are less typically associated.

diagnoses.name: Parkinson's Disease
diagnoses.description: Parkinson's disease is a progressive neurological disorder that affects movement. Symptoms include tremors, stiffness, and slowness of movement. It can also feature blepharospasm as a symptom. Cognitive issues, including attention deficits, can appear as the disease progresses.

diagnoses.name: Hypoparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypoparathyroidism is a condition in which the body produces insufficient parathyroid hormone, leading to low levels of calcium in the blood. This can cause bone pain as well as muscle spasms or cramps, which could be related to blepharospasm. Malabsorption could impact the disease severity by affecting nutrient uptake.

diagnoses.name: Dystonia
diagnoses.description: Dystonia involves involuntary muscle contractions that cause repetitive or twisting movements. Blepharospasm is a form of dystonia. While dystonia itself doesn't directly cause malabsorption, bone pain, or attention deficits, it's part of a broader spectrum of neurological disorders that could.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is transmitted by ticks and can cause a host of symptoms, varying from muscle and joint pain (potentially explaining bone pain) to neurological problems, which may include facial muscle spasm similar to blepharospasm and cognitive deficits. Malabsorption is less directly associated but could be impacted in overall health deterioration.

diagnoses: Gastrointestinal Disorders (such as Crohn's Disease or Ulcerative Colitis)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses: Hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome, associated with vascular anomalies)

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various health issues, including memory problems, weakness, and fatigue. It is crucial for maintaining healthy nerve cells and aids in the production of DNA and RNA.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: A skin disease that causes red, itchy scaly patches, most commonly on the knees, elbows, trunk, and scalp. Psoriasis is a common, long-term (chronic) disease with no cure. It can also affect the nails, leading to onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Allergic reaction
diagnoses.description: Allergies occur when your immune system reacts to a foreign substance such as pollen, bee venom, pet dander, or a food that doesn't cause a reaction in most people. Symptoms can include angioedema, irritated eyes, and in some cases, skin reactions.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears. Symptoms include dry eyes, dry mouth, joint pain, and fatigue. It might also impact cognitive functions, leading to memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Graves' disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that results in the overproduction of thyroid hormones (hyperthyroidism). While this condition is known to cause a range of symptoms, including anxiety and eye irritation, it's less commonly associated with onychodystrophy.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare, genetic disorder that results in recurring episodes of severe swelling. The swelling can occur in the limbs, face, intestinal tract, and airway. Memory problems are not directly linked to hereditary angioedema but could be related to complications or stress from the disorder.

diagnoses.name: Chronic stress or anxiety disorder
diagnoses.description: Chronic stress or an anxiety disorder can lead to a wide range of physical symptoms including digestive issues, headaches, and insomnia. Chronic stress can exacerbate or mimic the symptoms of other disorders, complicating diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Fibromyalgia can intensify stress and anxiety, potentially leading to cognitive issues.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A common but serious mood disorder. It can cause severe symptoms that affect how you feel, think, and handle daily activities. Depression is often accompanied by anxiety, memory problems, and other physical symptoms.

diagnoses.reasoning: PCOS can lead to the formation of ovarian cysts, affect glucose metabolism causing hyperglycemia, and is a known risk for miscarriage. Musculoskeletal pain and abdominal pain, although not typical, might be indirectly related through associated obesity or metabolic disturbances.

Hyperglycemia is a hallmark of uncontrolled diabetes, which can increase the risk of miscarriages and may explain muscle pain through associated diabetic myonecrosis or neuropathy. While not commonly associated with cysts or migratory abdominal pain, poorly controlled diabetes can lead to various complications that could manifest with these symptoms.

Thyroid disorders can cause menstrual irregularities and increase the risk of miscarriage. They can also lead to the development of thyroid cysts. Myalgia or muscle pain is common in thyroid disorders, and in severe cases, hyperglycemia can be related to the metabolic imbalances they cause.

diagnoses.diagnosis: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Systemic Lupus Erythematosus, SLE)
diagnoses.reasoning: Autoimmune diseases like SLE can cause a wide range of symptoms, including the development of cysts, muscle pain, and risks to pregnancy leading to miscarriage. Abdominal pain and hyperglycemia can also be manifestations, especially with the involvement of organs like the pancreas or liver.

RA can cause muscle pain and has been associated with increased risk of miscarriage. While RA itself might not directly cause cysts or hyperglycemia, it can be part of a larger autoimmune or systemic inflammatory response that includes these symptoms.

Endometriosis can cause cysts (endometriomas), is a known factor in some miscarriages, and can cause significant abdominal pain, which might be migratory depending on the extent and location of the tissue growths. While muscle pain and hyperglycemia are not classic symptoms, chronic pain could be generalized.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain, which could encompass abdominal and muscle pain. Association with miscarriage is not direct, but stress and sleep disruption common in fibromyalgia can potentially impact pregnancy. Hyperglycemia is not a direct symptom, but metabolic syndrome is more common in people with fibromyalgia.

Cushing's syndrome involves the overproduction of cortisol, which can lead to hyperglycemia. Its association with weight gain and potential for causing ovarian cysts, increased miscarriage rates, muscle weakness or pain, and abdominal pain makes it a condition to consider.

While often benign, ovarian cysts themselves can be symptomatic, causing abdominal pain, and in some cases, they may be associated with hormonal imbalances that could lead to hyperglycemia or affect pregnancy, potentially increasing the risk of miscarriage.

Chronic pancreatitis can cause abdominal pain, including migratory pain, and may lead to the development of cysts within the pancreas. It can also cause hyperglycemia due to the damage to insulin-producing cells. Links to muscle pain can come from nutritional malabsorption and miscarriage risk may rise with the general health impact of chronic illness.

diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells. This can lead to thickened blood and increased risk of blood clots. It might relate to increased immunoglobulins through secondary effects on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: Long-term stress can contribute to a variety of physical and mental health conditions, including takotsubo cardiomyopathy (stress-induced cardiomyopathy) and obsessive-compulsive behavior. It may also indirectly affect immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Diseases
diagnoses.description: Diseases where the immune system attacks the body's own tissues, potentially leading to increased immunoglobulins. Some autoimmune diseases can also result in symptoms similar to the ones described.

diagnoses.name: Primary Myelofibrosis
diagnoses.description: A rare bone marrow cancer leading to an abnormal increase in blood cells, which might present similarly to polycythemia. This condition can cause symptoms like an enlarged spleen and fullness in the abdomen, not directly linked to the specific symptoms but could be a complicating factor.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Polycythemia
diagnoses.description: Unlike polycythemia vera, this condition is caused by underlying factors such as chronic hypoxia or tumors producing erythropoietin. It could correlate with increased immunoglobulins if there is an underlying condition affecting the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Portal Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Increased blood pressure in the portal venous system, which can lead to hemorrhoids due to the increased pressure. The link to the other symptoms would be less direct, potentially through associated liver disease and its effects on overall health.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Liver Disease
diagnoses.description: Liver diseases can lead to symptoms like hemorrhoids due to portal hypertension, and can impact blood composition, potentially explaining increased immunoglobulins. Liver dysfunction could also contribute to a range of systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Including obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD), can result from or contribute to stress-related conditions like takotsubo cardiomyopathy. The link between anxiety disorders and the other symptoms would be more indirect.

diagnoses.name: Hemochromatosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder causing iron overload in the body, which might indirectly affect other organ systems and contribute to a complex symptom profile. It's a less direct fit but could explain a broad range of symptoms through systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Monoclonal Gammopathy of Undetermined Significance (MGUS)
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by an increased level of a specific type of immunoglobulin, known as a monoclonal protein. It is generally benign but can progress to serious conditions. This could potentially relate to the increased immunoglobulins, though it's less directly related to the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can occur rapidly after exposure to an allergen.

diagnoses.name: Food Allergy
diagnoses.description: An immune system reaction that occurs soon after eating a certain food, causing various symptoms including abdominal cramps, vomiting, and angioedema.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary Angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing swelling in various parts of the body, including the abdomen and airways, potentially leading to abdominal cramps and hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing cold-like signs and symptoms, such as a runny nose, itching, and sneezing. Often associated with conjunctivitis and asthma.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your airways narrow and swell and may produce extra mucus, leading to difficulty breathing, and possibly triggering hypoxia in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
diagnoses.description: A drug-induced condition marked by widespread rash, internal organ involvement, and various systemic symptoms, often including hypoxia, angioedema, and abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Mast Cell Activation Syndrome (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by inappropriate mast cell activation. Symptoms can include abdominal discomfort, skin lesions, and anaphylactoid reactions.

diagnoses.name: Nonsteroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drug (NSAID) Hypersensitivity
diagnoses.description: Reactions to NSAID medications, leading to symptoms like rhinorrhea, asthma exacerbations, angioedema, and gastrointestinal issues.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.description: Certain viruses can cause a range of symptoms, including rhinorrhea, abdominal cramps, vomiting, and in severe cases, respiratory distress leading to hypoxia.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain bacterial infections. Symptoms may include vomiting, rash, and hypotension, potentially leading to multi-organ failure.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Strokes may cause symptoms such as paralysis, speech difficulties, and muscle weakness.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. A TIA usually lasts only a few minutes and doesn't cause permanent damage. It’s often a warning sign of a future stroke.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor can be cancerous or non-cancerous (benign) and affects brain function, leading to symptoms such as headaches, speech problems, weakness, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: MS is a chronic illness involving your central nervous system. It interrupts the flow of information within the brain and between the brain and body, causing symptoms like weakness, speech difficulties, and chronic pain.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, ALS affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control. ALS often begins with muscle twitching and weakness in a limb, or slurred speech.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A migraine can be a severe headache often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and extreme sensitivity to light and sound. Migraine with aura involves visual disturbances and other neurological symptoms that appear about 20 to 60 minutes before the headache begins.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Primary Progressive Aphasia
diagnoses.description: A neurological syndrome in which language capabilities become progressively impaired. Unlike other forms of aphasia that result from stroke or brain injury, primary progressive aphasia worsens over time and is caused by neurodegenerative diseases.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually caused by a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can cause symptoms including headache, fever, weakness, and speech difficulties.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Encephalitis is inflammation of the brain caused by a viral infection or an autoimmune response. Symptoms include headache, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and fatigue. It may also lead to seizures or problems with movement or senses such as speech or hearing.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, visual disturbances (aura), sensitivity to light (photophobia), and sometimes sensory changes (numbness).

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a 'mini-stroke,' a TIA is a brief period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke, such as numbness and speech difficulties. Unlike a stroke, the symptoms of a TIA usually resolve within a few minutes to a couple of hours.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, seizures, numbness, speech difficulties (aphasia), and hearing problems (tinnitus).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system. It can cause a wide range of symptoms including numbness, weakness, loss of vision, and difficulty with coordination and speech.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. Symptoms can include severe headache, fever, photophobia, and in severe cases, altered mental status and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, fever, confusion, seizures, and sensory or motor deficits including aphasia and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Temporal Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disorder affecting large and medium-sized arteries. Symptoms can include severe headaches, jaw pain, vision complications, and sometimes symptoms of stroke like aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Intracranial Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: Bleeding inside the skull. Symptoms can include headache, nausea, seizures, numbness, weakness, and difficulties with speech and vision.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from the poor blood flow to the back of the brain. Symptoms can include headache, dizziness, visual disturbances, numbness, problems with coordination, and, in some cases, ringing in the ears (tinnitus) and aphasia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.details: Migraine headaches can sometimes present with numbness and weakness as aura symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.details: Sudden numbness or weakness of the face, arm, or leg, especially on one side of the body, along with headache, can signal a stroke.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.details: Characterized by symptoms like numbness, weakness, and sometimes headaches due to demyelination in the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.details: Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause temporary numbness, weakness, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.details: Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause headaches, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.details: Severe anemia can cause weakness, headaches, and occasionally numbness.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes
diagnoses.details: Uncontrolled diabetes can lead to peripheral neuropathy, which causes numbness and sometimes weakness, along with other symptoms like headaches.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.details: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Headaches, numbness, and weakness can also be present.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.details: Caused by a tick bite, its neurological manifestations can include headaches, numbness, and weakness.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.details: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, causing weakness and numbness starting in the feet and hands, sometimes accompanied by headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition characterized by intense headaches often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Cluster Headaches
diagnoses.description: Severe, recurring headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye, accompanied by redness, tearing, and nasal congestion.

diagnoses.name: Tension-Type Headache
diagnoses.description: A common type of headache characterized by dull, aching head pain, and tightness or pressure across the forehead or sides and back of the head.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. Symptoms include headache, fever, and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
diagnoses.description: An emergency condition in which there is bleeding into the space surrounding the brain. This can cause sudden, severe headache, nausea, vomiting, and photophobia.

diagnoses.name: Traumatic Brain Injury
diagnoses.description: An injury to the brain from an external force, potentially causing headaches, confusion, dizziness, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Glaucoma
diagnoses.description: A group of eye conditions that can cause blindness if left untreated, characterized by damage to the optic nerve. Early symptoms may include headaches and eye pain.

diagnoses.name: Benign Intracranial Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Also known as pseudotumor cerebri, it occurs when there is increased pressure in the brain without a clear reason, causing headaches, vision problems, and nausea.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can include headaches, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, balance problems, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Psychological disorders characterized by significant feelings of anxiety and fear. Symptoms can mimic or include headaches, nausea, and sensitivity to light.

diagnoses: Demyelinating diseases of the central nervous system

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness involving your central nervous system. The immune system attacks myelin, which is the protective layer around your nerve fibers, leading to delayed response or permanent nerve damage.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune, neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It’s frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A type of nerve damage that can occur with diabetes. It affects nerves leading to your extremities, as well as organs in your body, causing pain and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from reduced blood flow to the back part of the brain, which is supplied by the vertebrobasilar arterial system. Symptoms can include dizziness, difficulty walking, double vision, and slurred speech.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, and fatigue. It can later progress to neurological problems including paralysis and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: Also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, it's a progressive nervous system disease that affects nerve cells in the brain and spinal cord, causing loss of muscle control.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, causing a wide range of symptoms including nonscarring alopecia, leukopenia, and potentially cranial neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planopilaris
diagnoses.description: A type of lichen planus that affects the scalp, causing hair loss, which could potentially present with nonscarring alopecia if it affects other areas.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that produce saliva and tears. It can also affect other parts of the body, including the skin (potentially causing lichen planus), nerves (possibly leading to cranial neuropathy), and can cause leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. In rare cases, it can cause skin problems similar to lichen planus, leukopenia, and cranial neuropathy.

diagnoses.name: Graft versus Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when donor bone marrow or stem cells attack the recipient. It can cause a variety of skin problems, including those resembling lichen planus, as well as leukopenia and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body, leading to numerous symptoms, including skin lesions similar to lichen planus, and potentially affecting the nervous system (including cranial nerves).

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: The virus can cause a wide range of symptoms and opportunistic infections, with leukopenia being a common finding. HIV/AIDS patients might also experience various dermatologic manifestations, including lichen planus, and neurological complications.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection usually spread by sexual contact that can cause a wide range of presentations, from skin rashes to neurological symptoms, including cranial neuropathy. Skin manifestations could potentially resemble lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. It can cause a variety of symptoms, potentially including skin manifestations similar to lichen planus, neurological symptoms (such as cranial neuropathy), and in later stages, possibly leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinctive skin rash. While not typically associated with leukopenia or lichen planus directly, it can cause a range of skin conditions and, in severe cases, affect the muscles involved in swallowing, potentially impacting the cranial nerves.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body. Pleural effusion, hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and pericarditis are among the common manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily known for its effects on the joints, Rheumatoid Arthritis can also have systemic manifestations, including pleural effusions and pericarditis. Hemolytic anemia and oral ulcers could be related through both disease activity and medication side effects.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is an autoimmune disorder presenting with features of multiple diseases, including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, and may cause pleural effusion, hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Primarily affects the body's moisture-producing glands, but systemic manifestations can include pleural effusion and hemolytic anemia. Oral ulcers are also common, related to dryness.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Oral ulcers are a hallmark symptom, but it can also involve various organs, potentially causing pericarditis and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Cancers of lymphatic tissue can cause pleural effusion and, in some types, hemolytic anemia. Systemic symptoms could potentially include oral ulcers and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Leukemia
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of leukemia can cause hemolytic anemia and may be associated with pericarditis due to direct infiltration or through treatment effects. Pleural effusion and oral ulcers can also be manifestations or treatment side effects.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: A rare autoimmune disorder with simultaneous or sequential occurrence of autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia which may be associated with systemic autoimmune diseases that can cause pleural effusion and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: An autoimmune disorder that can cause a variety of symptoms, including blood clots and pregnancy complications. Secondary antiphospholipid syndrome may be associated with SLE and can cause hematologic abnormalities and potentially pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Parvovirus B19 Infection
diagnoses.rationale: Though usually causing erythema infectiosum in children, in adults, it can lead to hemolytic anemia. Its relation to the other symptoms would be less direct but could be associated with immune-mediated effects causing pericarditis.

diagnoses: Cancer (various types, including Leukemia and Lymphoma)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including alopecia, thrombocytopenia, and pleural effusion. Proteinuria indicates renal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.reason: Scleroderma can cause skin changes such as telangiectasias and nonscarring alopecia, as well as affecting internal organs leading to proteinuria and pleural effusions.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.reason: Dermatomyositis is associated with skin manifestations such as telangiectasias and alopecia, and can also involve internal organs, leading to pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.reason: MCTD is characterized by features of multiple autoimmune disorders, including SLE, scleroderma, and polymyositis, presenting symptoms like those listed.

diagnoses.name: Polymyositis
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting muscles, polymyositis can also have systemic manifestations such as those listed.

diagnoses.name: Atypical Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (aHUS)
diagnoses.reason: aHUS can lead to thrombocytopenia and kidney problems, possibly presenting with proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Some variants can cause skin manifestations and systemic symptoms, though this is a less common diagnosis for these particular symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.reason: Chronic Hepatitis C infection can cause cryoglobulinemia, leading to symptoms such as proteinuria, thrombocytopenia, and vasculitic skin lesions.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of vasculitis could cause a combination of these symptoms depending on the severity and organs involved.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria (PNH)
diagnoses.reason: Though primarily affecting blood cells, PNH can have systemic implications and might present with thrombocytopenia and possibly hemoglobinuria misinterpreted as proteinuria.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, causing inflammation and tissue damage in the affected parts, including joints, skin, kidneys, heart, lungs, blood vessels, and brain.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by features commonly seen in lupus, scleroderma, polymyositis, and rheumatoid arthritis. It may present with a combination of symptoms including those mentioned.

diagnoses.name: Behcet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body. Symptoms can include mouth sores, eye inflammation, skin rashes and lesions, and genital sores.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause a wide variety of systemic symptoms, including hemolytic anemia and skin manifestations similar to lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth, causing dryness but can also present with systemic manifestations including hematologic and cutaneous symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Pemphigus Vulgaris
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder characterized by blistering and erosion of the skin and mucous membranes, including oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A broader term that includes various forms of lupus, such as discoid lupus and systemic lupus erythematosus, both of which can present with the symptoms described.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare autoimmune disorder characterized by the combination of immune thrombocytopenia (ITP) and autoimmune hemolytic anemia (AIHA). Although less commonly associated with the dermatologic and cardiac symptoms, its presence could complicate with similar manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rash. While primarily affecting the skin and muscles, it can also involve the lungs, heart, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Polyarteritis Nodosa
diagnoses.description: A serious blood vessel disease where small and medium-sized arteries become swollen and damaged. Although not always presenting with the listed symptoms, it could include skin, heart, and other systemic involvements.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.reason: SLE can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including neurological symptoms (e.g., cranial neuropathy, delirium), skin manifestations (e.g., lichen planus-like lesions, nonscarring alopecia), and hematological abnormalities such as thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Certain types of vasculitis could present with a combination of skin, neurological, and hematological manifestations. This group of diseases includes those that could lead to cranial neuropathies, thrombocytopenia, and skin changes similar to lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Vasculitis
diagnoses.reason: Lupus vasculitis is part of the spectrum of SLE manifestations, specifically affecting blood vessels and potentially leading to skin, neurological, and hematological symptoms as described.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lichen Planus
diagnoses.reason: Some medications can induce lichen planus or lichenoid reactions, which may accompany other systemic symptoms depending on the drug and the individual’s reaction to it, potentially affecting the nervous system and blood elements.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planus with Neurological Manifestations
diagnoses.reason: While rare, there are reported cases where lichen planus is associated with neurological complaints, including neuropathies and cognitive symptoms like delirium.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.reason: Behçet's disease is a vasculitis that can present with mucocutaneous, neurologic, and hematologic manifestations similar to the symptoms described.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Sjögren's syndrome can cause nonscarring alopecia, cranial neuropathy due to peripheral nerve involvement, and hematologic disturbances, although lichen planus is not a direct manifestation, patients might have overlapping autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease (GVHD)
diagnoses.reason: In post-transplant patients, GVHD can resemble with skin changes (including lichen planus-like eruptions), neurological symptoms, and thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses.name: Hypereosinophilic Syndrome
diagnoses.reason: Though less common, hypereosinophilic syndrome can affect multiple organ systems including the skin, nervous system, and blood, potentially mimicking the described symptom constellation.

diagnoses.name: Paraneoplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.reason: Certain cancers can induce systemic reactions leading to dermatological manifestations (like lichen planus), neurological symptoms including neuropathies and cognitive changes, and hematological abnormalities such as thrombocytopenia.

diagnoses: Hepatitis B or C associated arthropathy
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
